content: I think I would like to make it a requirement of stabiliztion that we document the features in the reference. There was an RFC to this effect as I require, and sometimes we do, but I don't feel like we've made it as complete a part of our procedure as we could (am I wrong?). To start, I created a column of things that need documenting in our project board, but I wanted to open up the topic for the best way to go about working towards completeness of the reference

The only way to require docs is to have reviewers require the docs to be written. The process is written down, it's no secret, but some people don't want to do it. Maybe better understanding of why that is could help.
• I am not convinced that reference material should block stabilization, but maybe it should
I like the way that Ember phrasing things:
there is a phase where things are stable and a distinct phase where they are recommended for use
it is quite likely that this should be the exception, not the norm
I think then the other problem is
• we have no template or checklist for stabilization reports

Eric Huss said:

The process is written down, it's no secret

in other words, I don't really agree with this =)

I think there is at least a checklist written here: https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/stabilization_guide.html, along with some (semi-broken) links to example reports. The first section there spells out what needs to be done documentation-wise.
I also find that the documentation phase is a good process for ensuring that you are stabilizing what you think you are stabilizing.

I think it's fine if someone doesn't want to write the documentation for whatever reason, but I think it would be good to somehow make it part of the process. Either enlisting someone to help, or at least writing a good stabilization report that outlines what the thing does.
